metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State (Criminal Appeal Nos. 130 and 25 of 1956)
metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 and Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956, the appellant was convicted under s.5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 by the Special Judge, Delhi and sentenced to six months simple imprisonment.
The appellant in Cr. A. No. 130/1956 appealed to the Punjab High Court, which dismissed the appeal and enhanced the sentence to two years rigorous imprisonment.
In Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956, the appellant applied to the Allahabad High Court under s.561A CrPC for quashing proceedings before the Special Judge; application dismissed.
At the time the Special Judge purported to take cognizance, the appellants were not public servants, and no order of sanction under s.6 of the Act was on record.
At the time the appellants are alleged to have committed the offence, they were public servants.
Appellant in Cr. A. No. 25/1956 appointed Deputy Assistant Director Enforcement on March 25, 1949; promoted to Assistant Director on July 14, 1949.
Appellant in Cr. A. No. 25/1956 alleged to have accepted Rs.10,000 as bribe on September 11, 1951.
Appellant in Cr. A. No. 25/1956 dismissed from service on September 25, 1953 following enquiry under r.55 Civil Service Rules.
Final report under s.173 CrPC submitted on September 18, 1952 stating prosecution recommended but Ministry ordered departmental dealing.
Magistrate approved closing investigation, discharged appellant from bail, and directed return of Rs.10,000 to complainant on September 19, 1952.
Prosecution recommenced on February 11, 1954 on fresh complaint with same materials and allegations.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was any necessity for a sanction under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 before a court could take cognizance of an offence under s.161 IPC or s.5(2) of the Act or both, alleged to have been committed by a person who at the time the court was asked to take cognizance was not a public servant but was so at the time of the commission of the offence.
In Cr. A. No. 25/1956: Whether prosecution could be recommenced after earlier closure without sanction, and if there was abuse of process.

petitioner_arguments.text: On a proper interpretation of s.6 of the Act, the status of the accused at the time of the commission of the offence alleged against him was the essence of the matter and not his status at the time the court was asked to take cognizance, in which case a sanction under s.6 was necessary before a court could take cognizance although at that stage the accused had ceased to be a public servant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; s.197 CrPC; precedents like S.Y. Patil v. Vyankatswami; Suganchand v. Seth Naraindas

petitioner_arguments.text: In construing s.6, court must ascertain legislative intention from language, social conditions, mischief remedied; cl.(c) s.6(1) applies to persons ceased to be public servants.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher; Art.361 Constitution; s.197A CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: In Cr. A. No. 25/1956: Once sanction refused or prosecution dropped, cannot be revived; promise not to prosecute; abuse of process to recommence.

respondent_arguments.text: On a proper interpretation of s.6, not only must the offence be committed by a public servant but that person must still be a public servant removable from office at the time court asked to take cognizance.

In Cr. A. No. 25/1956: No positive refusal of sanction; Government proceeded departmentally, kept option open; withdrawal resulted in discharge, not bar to fresh complaint after ceasing to be public servant.

court_reasoning.text: s.6 requires two conditions: offence committed by public servant AND person still employed/not removable save by competent authority at time of cognizance; if either lacking, no sanction needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words in s.6(1) clear: 'alleged to have been committed by a public servant' and sanctions for persons 'employed' and 'not removable' or 'competent to remove him from his office' â€“ applies only if still public servant at cognizance.

court_reasoning.text: Object of Act to suppress corruption severely; s.6 protects public servants from frivolous prosecution while in office, but does not absolve after ceasing office.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition on cognizance confined to terms; no protection post-cessation.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents on s.197 CrPC support: protection only if public servant at time of accusation/cognizance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State v. Hifzul Rahman overrules S.Y. Patil; similar in Calcutta, Bombay, Allahabad, Punjab HCs.

court_reasoning.text: In Cr. A. No. 25/1956: No positive sanction refusal; departmental proceedings first; discharge not bar to fresh complaint post-cessation when no sanction needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence shows preference for departmental action, not refusal; withdrawal mere discharge.

holdings.text: No sanction under s.6 required if accused ceased to be public servant at time of cognizance, though was at time of offence; provisions of s.6 do not apply, prosecution not vitiated.
Prosecution can be recommenced on fresh complaint after earlier discharge, especially post-cessation of public service when no sanction needed; no abuse of process.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher
precedents_cited.relevance: On construing ambiguous statutes to ascertain legislative intention.
Held s.197 CrPC applies even after ceasing office; overruled.
Similar to S.Y. Patil on s.197 CrPC.
s.197 CrPC requires public servant status at time of accusation.
s.197 protection only if still public servant at prosecution launch.
Similar to Prasad Chandra on s.197 CrPC.
s.197 requires current public servant status.
s.197 and s.6 Act similar; no protection post-discharge.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction required only if still public servant at cognizance for offences under s.161/164/165 IPC or s.5(2); creates criminal misconduct offence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences requiring sanction; defines public servant.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to take cognizance prohibited without sanction; quashing proceedings; final reports.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Appoints Special Judges to try specified corruption offences without committal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Referred but not assistive in construing s.6.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held that no sanction under s.6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act was required as appellants had ceased to be public servants at time of cognizance; provisions of s.6 inapplicable and prosecution not vitiated. For Cr. A. No. 25/1956, no refusal of sanction and recommencement valid post-discharge from service. Appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "No court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 164 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code... alleged to have been committed by a public servant, except with the previous sanction..."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Both these conditions must be present to prevent a court from taking cognizance... If either of these conditions is lacking, the essential requirements of the section are wanting."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on dual requirements for s.6 applicability.

key_quotes.text: "The mere fact that he had ceased to be a public servant after the commission of the offence would not absolve him from his crime."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies s.6 does not condone offence post-cessation.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion... the conclusion is inevitable that at the time a court is asked to take cognizance not only the offence must have been committed by a public servant but the person accused is still a public servant..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
